Instead It has two more records). In the example you shared, there are two fuzzy matching records (IP01547 | EApp Guest User Ip Address Log | Salesforce, IP22868 | EApp Guest User Ip Address Log | Salesforce) the applicaiton was marked as SPAM because one of the IP address log record is flagged as SPAM)Fix:Fortunately, duplicate fuzzy IPs are not being created any more. The last duplicate fuzzy IP record was created only on 12/17. So, there is no code fix needed.We only need to fix the data by getting rid of duplicate fuzzy IP records and reparent applications as needed. Amit is currently working on the list. We will share it with your for review soon. @Omololu Osazuwa @Denise Dyer @Kelly Avolio

Title: 2 - Complete Solutioning
Details: Mentioned in System.History: @Kelly Avolio For Scenario 7, the business requested that the Phone field be part of the Contact Information section. However, this section is rendered through a separate LWC, which we cannot modify. Since it was already mentioned that this can be ignored if compliance allows, I believe we can proceed without addressing this item.Regarding the Campus field, the business has requested that it be either:A picklist, orAuto-populated based on Duty StationCurrently:The Campus field is required on the record page.Leads may be created without a Duty Station, which makes enforcing Campus as required problematic.We already have backend automation that updates the Campus field when Duty Station changes (update scenario only).Regarding changing the Campus field to a picklist:This field is heavily used across integrations and multiple code references.Changing its data type would introduce significant risk and could break existing functionality.Therefore, converting the existing Campus field to a picklist would be a major and unsafe change.Proposed Solution:Create a new picklist field (e.g., Campus Selection).Replace the original Campus field with this new picklist on the page layout/ record page and make it required.Implement automation so that when a value is selected in the new picklist, it populates the original Campus field.Continue to use the original Campus field for integrations and backend logic, ensuring no downstream impact.Please let me know your thoughts on this approach

Details: Mentioned in System.History: From: Michael Watts <michael.watts@umgc.edu>Sent: Tuesday, January 13, 2026 10:00 AMTo: Chris Van Der Merwe <Christiaan.VanDerMerwe@umgc.edu>; Prakash Sriram <prakash.sriram@umgc.edu>Cc: Kyle Berry <kyle.berry@umgc.edu>; Kelly Avolio <kelly.avolio@umgc.edu>; Keith Riggs <thomas.riggs@umgc.edu>; Vijaya Gollapudi <vijaya.gollapudi@umgc.edu>Subject: 📋 Call Follow-up — Installed Packages & 3rd-Party Integration Process Hi everyone,Thank you again for the discussion around standardizing our process for Salesforce Installed Packages and 3rd-Party Integrations. I wanted to share a final clarification on the scope and expectations of the SOP, incorporating our latest alignment.The SOP will begin with the Solution — not Intake.Existing intake paths (CRM Request Form, internal ADO ticket creation, Fast Track triage) remain unchanged and are out of scope for this document.Where the SOP startsThe SOP applies once an Admin or Developer has identified that the solution involves:Installing a Salesforce Installed Package (managed or unmanaged), orImplementing a 3rd-party integration.From that point forward, the SOP should define what is required to successfully prepare the solution for:Solution Review (Architect and/or Senior Resource)Security and Compliance ReviewRelease Management executionWhat the Solution must includeIn addition to technical and architectural details, the Solution must clearly document:Step-by-step implementation approachRequired pre-deployment tasks (environment readiness, prerequisites, permissions, setup)Required post-deployment tasks (validation, monitoring, reconciliation, rollback considerations)Sandbox testing strategy and scenariosSecurity and compliance considerationsThe goal is to ensure that Solution Reviews are efficient and that Release Managers receive work that is fully vetted, implementation-ready, and clearly documented.Next StepsPlease review the draft SOP and help me fully define the Solution and Solution Review sections. Also help me define Task Templates and/or User Story Templates that I can add on to this documentation.​[SOP-001] Installed Packages & 3rd Party Integrations - Salesforce.docx​​[SOP-001-APP-A] ADO Task Template -- 2a - [Solution] - Complete - XXXXXX​​[SOP-001-APP-B] ADO Task Template -- 2b - [Solution] - Review - XXXXXX​​[SOP-001-APP-C] ADO Task Template -- XX - [Security and Compliance] - Review - XXXXXX.docx​​[SOP-001-APP-D] ADO Task Template -- XX - [Release Management] - Delivery - XXXXXX.docx​For a summary the call yesterday, you can view in more detail within the comment section of User Story 250519.I will schedule a follow-up meeting to review/finalize the SOP related the Solution / Solution Review section.Thank you again for your assistance and collaboration,Michael Watts

Title: Roll Over of Open Cases with Last Modified Date >30 Days Ago
Details: Mentioned in System.History: @Kelly Avolio @Evan Natelson The way I have been building this, it isn't actually dependent on the Department record, as the Department is not granular enough in many cases anyway. For example, many departments have multiple roles that work different queues - as one example, the Admissions Services department has the main Admissions Services team and the Residency team, so based on the role the Residency cases would need to route to the Residency queue instead. As a result, all we need to reference in the flow is the Case Owner User's UMGC Department and User Role fields, so no new Department values are needed. (Also, as an additional piece of this, the queues listed on Department are Action queues for Omni-Channel, not Case queues, so if we did want to use the Department object for this we would also need to add Case queue values for the existing Departments.) So as a result, all we need to do here is define a desired queue for case escalation for System Administrators.

Title: Enable Security Event Monitoring for eApp Salesforce Environment
Details: Mentioned in System.History: @Kelly Avolio @Chris Van Der Merwe @Denise Dyer @Evan Natelson @Prakash Sriram Thank you -- I am looking through the scenario's and to enable the visibility within the SEIM, the following would need to be done by a Salesforce administrator:The Exabeam Cloud Connectors platform uses user information to integrate with Salesforce cloud application APIs. Creating a user account specifically for the cloud connector ensures better visibility and security.To create a Salesforce user:Log in to the Salesforce console as an administrator.Navigate to Setup > Administration > Users > Users.Click New User.Specify a user name and enter other details. Ensure that you assign a role, profile, and user license to the new user. You can assign any role to the user. The user license must match the license assigned to a user profile that you selected for the new user. For more information, see Add a New user.To obtain a user password, select the Generate new password and notify user immediately checkbox.Click Save.The User Details page displays the details you entered. Note the password that Salesforce emailed you. If you want to reset the password, on the User Details page, click Reset Password. Salesforce sends an email to the user’s email address with a link to reset the password. Reset the password using the link that you received on your email address. Note the username and password of the Salesforce user that you created. You will need the username and password when you configure the Salesforce Cloud Connector on the Exabeam Cloud Connectors platform. Obtain an API TokenSalesforce APIs are authenticated through API token, also known as security token. The Exabeam Cloud Connectors platform uses an API token to integrate with Salesforce cloud application APIs, and retrieve audit log events, changes, and other data. The cloud connector uses audit logs and other data for security monitoring to analyze and handle security threats.To obtain the Salesforce API token:Log in to the Salesforce console using the user name and password of the user that you created.Click the profile image in the upper right corner, then click Settings.In the right pane, navigate to My Personal Information > Reset My Security Token.Click Reset Security Token to have Salesforce generate a new security token and send it to you via email.Record the security token, represented by letters and numbers, that you receive via email. Use the security token while configuring the Salesforce Cloud Connector on the Exabeam Cloud Connectors platform.via: https://docs.exabeam.com/en/cloud-connectors/all/configuration/132990-salesforce-cloud-connector.htmlSharing this as a step that will need to be done. @Kelly Avolio, from a timing standpoint, when would this work be anticipated to be started?
